content.description:
Researchers were modeling the effects of repeated cycles of isolation with occasional interbreeding among five hypothetical fish species (species A, B, C, D, and E) found in two separate lakes (lakes <math alttext="one" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="two" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that are occasionally joined by flooding, as shown in Figure 1. The research team indicated that species A would be considered to be the single common ancestor of species B, C, D, and E.

Figure 1. Current locations of populations of fish species A, B, C, D, and E
content.question: Which of the following mechanisms could most likely account for the origin of species <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Lake <math alttext="one" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

skill.text: 2.B: Explain relationships between characteristics of biological models in both theoretical and applied contexts.
